prior_works.title: Targeted Learning: Causal Inference for Observational and Experimental Data
prior_works.authors: Mark J. van der Laan, Sherri Rose
prior_works.role: Foundational targeted learning/TMLE and efficient influence functions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper adapts targeted learning to the networked interference setting and converts EIF-based double-robust conditions into a targeted loss for training neural networks, directly building on the TMLE framework laid out by van der Laan and Rose.

prior_works.title: Doubly robust estimation in missing data and causal inference
prior_works.role: Core double robustness principle and AIPW construction
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The proposed estimator’s double-robustness property under networked interference extends the classical Bang–Robins doubly robust paradigm to settings with dependence between units.

prior_works.title: Toward causal inference with interference
prior_works.authors: Michael G. Hudgens, M. Elizabeth Halloran
prior_works.role: Foundational framework for interference and estimands
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The interference framework and estimands considered in the new work trace back to Hudgens and Halloran’s formalization of causal effects under interference, which the paper generalizes beyond partial interference.

prior_works.title: Doubly robust estimation of causal effects in the presence of partial interference
prior_works.authors: Lan Liu, Michael G. Hudgens, Stephanie M. Becker-Dreps, (and co-authors)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work established doubly robust estimators for partial interference; the ICML 2024 paper generalizes the DR idea to general networked interference and operationalizes it via a targeted-loss training procedure.

prior_works.title: Causal inference for social network data
prior_works.authors: Elizabeth L. Ogburn, Oleg Sofrygin, Iván Díaz, Mark J. van der Laan
prior_works.role: Identification and semiparametric theory for network-dependent data
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper builds on semiparametric identification and EIF-based reasoning for network settings discussed by Ogburn et al., extending these ideas to derive conditions ensuring double robustness under network dependence.

prior_works.title: Targeted maximum likelihood estimation for network-dependent data (TMLE under interference)
prior_works.authors: Oleg Sofrygin, Mark J. van der Laan
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Prior TMLE developments for network-dependent outcomes by Sofrygin and van der Laan provide the template for constructing targeted updates under dependence, which the new paper adapts and embeds into neural network training.

prior_works.title: Estimating Average Causal Effects Under General Interference, with Applications
prior_works.role: General interference framework and exposure mappings
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By formalizing general interference via exposure mappings and identification conditions, this work informs the problem setup and estimands that the paper targets with its doubly robust targeted-learning estimator.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s key contribution—an end-to-end, doubly robust estimator for causal effects under networked interference realized via a targeted-learning loss—sits at the intersection of three strands of prior work. First, the targeted learning/TMLE framework of van der Laan and Rose provides the blueprint for constructing estimators by aligning model fitting with the efficient influence function (EIF). The authors explicitly leverage this by translating the EIF-driven estimating equations into a targeted loss to train neural networks, preserving robustness properties central to TMLE. Second, the concept of double robustness originates in Bang and Robins, who showed how augmented estimators remain consistent if either the outcome or treatment mechanism is correctly specified. Liu et al. extended DR ideas to partial interference; the present paper generalizes DR to general network dependence and embeds it into an EIF-targeted neural objective, addressing misspecification common in flexible ML models. Third, foundational identification and modeling under interference from Hudgens and Halloran, as well as general interference formulations and exposure mappings by Aronow and Samii, define the estimands and assumptions for networked settings. Complementary semiparametric theory for network data by Ogburn, Sofrygin, Diaz, and van der Laan, and TMLE extensions to network-dependent outcomes by Sofrygin and van der Laan, inform how to derive and target the EIF under dependence. Integrating these, the paper advances a theoretically grounded, practically implementable targeted-learning approach that achieves double robustness in complex networked environments.
